Laura C. Bolton and Angelin T. Arthur, plaintiffs and appellants, vs. James Jacks, et al. defendants and respondents. 1. Want of jurisdiction renders void the judgment of any court, whether of superior or inferior, general or limited, or local jurisdiction, and the recital of jurisdictional facts in the record of such judgment is not conclusive, (unless made so by statute,) but only prima facie evidence of the existence or occurrence of such facts; the party against whom the record of such judgment is offered in evidence is not estopped by such recitals from showing affirmatively by proof dehors the record, that they are untrue, and thus avoiding the judgment. 2. So held in regard to recitals in the record of admission of a will to probate by a surrogate, whose jurisdiction depended on the actual existence of jurisdictional facts, and not on the production of evidence of them, before such surrogate, merely hy a verified petition or otherwise. Parties affected by the decree admitting such will to probate, are not precluded from showing in a collateral action the non-existence of such matters, in order to defeat the claim of jurisdiction and consequent binding nature of the decree, notwithstanding the recital of them in the record of such admission. 3. Different heads of jurisdiction, their subdivisions and the various kinds exercised, stated. Ter Jones, J. 4. When a record shows jurisdiction of the subject matter on its face, by reciting the existence of facts conferring it, proof of such facts by evidence aliunde is unnecessary. 5. A surrogate to whom a will is presented for probate, has power to ascertain, preliminarily to exercising jurisdiction, whether the circumstances exist or have occurred, which confer it. And although no petition is required by statute to be presented to him, or proof taken by him, of what county in the state the testator was an inhabitant at the time of his death, yet if he require that or any other fact, upon which his jurisdiction to admit such will to probate rests, to be_stated in a verified petition upon which to issue a citation to all parties interested, and that is made part of the record of the admission of such will to probate, the statement of such facts in such petition is prima facie evidence of their existence or occurrence, although not conclusive. 6. The statement of jurisdictional facts'in such a petition, is as much a recital in the record and prima fade evidence of their existence, as if recited in a petition or bill in equity, or a declaration at law, when they or the jurisdiction of the court are attempted to be collaterally attacked. 7. No evidence is required by statute to be introduced, dehors the record, of the admission of a will to probate by a surrogate, when it states the facts which gives him jurisdiction, before it is admissible in evidence. The judgment or decree which admits it to probate, is made by statute, authority for recording it, and when jurisdiction appears from facts stated on the face of the whole *167record, such record is rendered admissible in evidence by provisions , in the same statute. 8. A commissioner of deeds, having authority to administer oaths, in all cases where no special provision is made by law, petitions to a surrogate for the probate of a will may be verified before such commissioner, as there is no special provision requiring it to be verified before such surrogate or any other designated officer. 9. The surrogate of a county, whereof a decedent was not an inhabitant, at and immediately preceding the time of his death, is not invested by statute with jurisdiction to admit to probate any instrument purporting to be the will of such decedent, if he were an inhabitant of another county at and immediately preceding the time of his death, even although he died seised of real estate in the former county. And the decree of such surrogate admitting such instrument to probate as the last will and testament of such decedent, may be questioned for want of such jurisdiction, by proof (dehors such record of admission,) that the decedent was not at the time of his death an inhabitant of the county in which such will was admitted to probate, but of a different one. 10. Unless a surrogate has jurisdiction to admit a will to probate, he has no power, of his own motion, to appoint a guardian for infants, in the proceedings consequent on an application to admit such will to probate; and therefore cannot, merely by unlawfully assuming jurisdiction to appoint a guardian for infants, conclude the infants; by the acts of such guardian, from contesting collaterally his right, either to appoint the guardian or to admit the will to probate." 11. Even where a surrogate has jurisdiction, and the probate of a will is consequently perfectly valid, it is questionable whether such probate is more than prima fade evidence of the due execution and validity of the will, subject to be rebutted by affirmative proof. Per Jones, J. 12. An executor, to whom a power of sale is given by will to sell land, and pay and apply the proceeds for the benefit of certain objects of the testator’s bounty named in such will, (according to provisions therein contained,) and not merely to apply the same in the administration of such estate as executor, is the donee of a power in trust, and takes as such, and not as executor, and derives his right to exercise it from the will itself, and not from its admission to probate, or letters testamentary thereon. He may therefore execute such power before such probate or issuing of letters testamentary. 13. A trust in real estate, in favor of the minor children of a testator, is not rendered void by an implication, that the will creating it provides for the accumulation of its rents and profits, not exclusively for their benfefit, but for that of an adult also. 14. Although no accumulation of rents and profits during the minority of an infant, can be for his benefit, unless payable to him upon his coming of age, yet, inasmuch as a matter of necessity it must terminate on his death under age, such death becomes necessarily a qualification of the statutory provisions respecting accumulation, and the author of it has a right to dispose of such fund in advance, in case of such death occurring, or allow it to sink into the rest of bis estate, if created by will, or revert to himself, if by grant, *16815. The invalidity of a trust for the accumulation of rents and profits of re& estate, created by .will, does not affect other provisions therein which are independent of it. If a valid trust of such real estate is clearly otherwise created in such will, for the benefit of the beneficiary of such rents and profits, and part of them are to be applied to his use, the only effect qf such invalidity will be to entitle such beneficiary to the benefit of the whole of such rents and profits. Ter Jones, J. 16. Provisions in a will having no necessary connection with a devise over of real estate not to take effect until the termination of three lives, are not necessarily affected by the invalidity of such devise. 17. A power of sale given tci carry out a trust in favor of certain objects of bounty continues operative as long as such trust lasts, 18. What is sufficient evidence to require the submission to a jury of the ques • tion whether a will was procured by undue influence. Ter Jones, J. 19. An omission to recite in a conveyance of real estate sufficient to pass a good title to the grantee, a power of sale, under which alone the grantor has a right to convey, and the execution of it by him without stating his representative or fiduciary capacity, will not defeat such conveyance. 20. Mere proof of non-payment of the consideration qf a deed, not sufficient primarily to infect the transaction with fraud, is not by itself admissible in a court of law to invalidate it, where a good title would otherwise pass by it. But a grantee, who seeks to shelter himself against the consequences of a fraud committed by his grantor, under the bona fides of his purchase, may, and is bound to prove the payment of such consideration, as well as any other circumstances which the shape of his case may require. His title is not derived alone from the conveyance to him, but from that as fortified by the bona fides of his purchase. 21. The case of Wood v. Chapin^ (8 Kern. 509,) is not authority that the recital of the receipt of its consideration in a conveyance is sufficient in all cases, if uncontradicted, to establish the purchase by the grantee of the property conveyed thereby for a valuable consideration, in hostility to a person claiming, either adversely to such grantee or under the grantor by a title prior to the execution of such conveyance. The decision in that case was confined to cases arising under the recording acts.

(Before Monell, Garvin and Jones, JJ.)

Heard February —, 1866; decided April —, 1868. This was an action of ejectment, to recover possession of certain lands situate in the city and county of Hew York. The plaintiffs claimed as sole heirs at law of a Mr. Tallmadge, (Theodore B.) who they allege died intestate, seisecl of the premises in question. The defendants alleged that Tallmadge left a will, which was duly proven, and upon which *169letters testamentary were issued to the executor therein named, and that it contained a power of sale of such premises, and that by certain deeds executed by such executor, under that power of sale, the title was out of the plaintiff. The cause was tried before Justice Bosworth and a j ury. On the trial, the plaintiffs proved that the decedent died in January, 1841, at Hudson in Columbia county, where he had been boarding for some weeks prior to his death, having his wife and family with him. It also appeared from the evidence on the trial, that at, and immediately previous to his decease, he was a resident and inhabitant of Columbia county. The counsel for the defendants admitted that the plaintiffs were the only children and heirs at law of the decedent; that his widow was deceased; that he died seised of the premises in question, and that the defendants were in possession; upon which the plaintiffs rested their case. The defendants then produced from the records of the office of the surrogate of the county of New York, what purported to be a copy and record of the will of the decedent, and offered the same in evidence, to which the plaintiffs objected, on several grounds as follows, to wit: 1st. That the record did not show jurisdiction by such surrogate of the subject matter, and it could not be presumed. 2d. That no proof had been offered, aliunde, of the necessary facts to confer jurisdiction. 3d. That the record on its face showed a want of jurisdiction over the persons of the plaintiffs, by the absence of proof of the service of a citation on the special guardian of the plaintiffs. . 4th. That there was no statutory provision allowing such record to be used in evidence, until it should be shown by other evidence, that the surrogate, whose record was offered, was the proper surrogate having jurisdiction. 5th. That it appeared on the face of the record that the necessary proof was not adduced before the surrogate of New York to entitle the will to be admitted to probate. *170Which objections were overruled, and such record was admitted in evidence; to which the counsel for the plaintiffs excepted. Such record set forth, that upon due application for that' purpose to the surrogate of the county of Hew York a citation was duly issued, which, with proof of service thereof, was afterwards duly returned to the surrogate, (which last consisted of an affidavit of the service thereof on the widow of the testator;) and that the special guardian of the infants, (being the present plaintiffs,) personally appeared before the surrogate and attended on the proving of the w.ill, whereof a copy was then set out. This was followed by an examination of the executor before the surrogate, wherein the executor testified that he received the instrument then shown him, purporting to be the last will of Mr. Tallmadge, bearing date April 13, 1839, from the testator in his life, immediately after the execution of the same; that it remained in his custody until he brought the same to the surrogate’s office, when he deposited it for record, and while in his custody was in no respect altered or changed; then came a deposition of John McCahill, whose name was subscribed as a witness to such instrument, before said surrogate, wherein he testified that he was well acquainted with the testator in his lifetime; that he was present as a witness, and saw him subscribe his name to such instrument ; that such subscription was made by the testator in the presence of two witnesses; that the testator at the same time declared it to be his last will and testament, whereupon the witness subscribed his name as a witness at the end thereof, in the presence of and at the request of the testator, and that the testator at the time of executing and publishing the said will, was of full age, of sound mind and memory, and not under any restraint, and was in all respects competent to devise real estate; also that he saw "William H. Bulkley, then of the city of Hew York, since deceased, sign said will as a witness in the presence and at the request of the testator. This was succeeded by the de*171position of William H. Bunn, before said surrogate, testifying that he knew said Bulkley then deceased, was well acquainted with his handwriting, and had often seen him write; that he verily believed and had no doubt but that the signature “ William H. Bulkley ” subscribed, as a witness to said instrument was the proper signature and handwriting of Bulkley, and that Bulkley was deceased; and also of Thomas Harrison before the same surrogate, testifying that he was well acquainted with Theodore B. Tallmadge, late of the city of New York and his handwriting, having often seen him write; that he verily believed and had no doubt, but that the signature “ Theodore B. Tallmadge,” subscribed to said instrument was the proper signature and handwriting of said Theodore B. Tallmadge. The counsel for the defendants then offered in evidence the original petition presented to the surrogate of New York county, praying that a citation might be issued requiring the widow, next of kin and heirs at law of Theodore B. Tallmadge, to appear at a time and place to be therein mentioned and attend the probate of said will, the original citation issued thereon and proof of its service on the widow. To the reception of which petition the counsel for the plaintiffs objected on the grounds: 1st. That it was not proof of the facts therein stated, to confer jurisdiction. 2d. Because it was sworn to before a commissioner of deeds, and not before the surrogate, (as required by statute.) 3d. Because it formed no part of the record. Which objections were overruled and such petition and proof admitted ; to which exception was taken by the counsel for the plaintiffs. The petition was verified on the 11th May, 1841. An order directing that a citation returnable ten days afterwards be issued. A consent signed by Isaac Eitz to be appointed guardian of the plaintiffs, then infants, an order appointing said Eitz such guardian, all dated the same day, and an order *172dated the 28th May, 1841, establishing such will as valid, and directing it to be admitted to probate and ■ recorded, were then read in evidence. The petition was verified before a commissioner of deeds, who was the chief cleric of the surrocate, and set forth, that Theodore B. Tallmadge departed this' life at the city of New York, having made his last will, devising both real and personal estate and appointing the petitioner his executor; that he left him surviving his widow and his children, Laura E. and Angelina, both under twenty-one years of age and having no general guardian, his only next of kin and heirs at law, and that said deceased was at or immediately previous to his death an inhabitant of the county of New York. The defendants then offered evidence of the execution of the will, on the trial, after establishing that the original was lost. For that purpose they called a witness who testified that the copy of the will and the proof taken on its probate, contained in the records of the surrogate’s office, were in the handwriting of Thomas J. Ireland, who was then recording clerk in the surrogate’s office; that Ireland was deceased; that it was the uniform practice of the office, and' a part of his (the witness’) duty to compare with Ireland the original wills proved, and the proofs taken on their probate, with the copies thereof made by Ireland in the records; that he had no doubt but that the will in question, and the proofs thereof, were compared in this way with the copies offered in evidence; that he invariably attended to this comparison; that there was no other clerk to attend to this business; that this business of comparison was part of his duties, given to him to perform, exclusively of any other clerk; that he was 'probate clerk at this time; that by the practice of the office, all wills propounded for probate, when brought into the office, were delivered to him and remained in his possession until they were admitted to probate, when he delivered them to the recording clerk to be recorded; that he prepared the petition for the citation, and the affida*173vits and depositions of the witnesses on proving this particular will. It appeared from that copy of this will, and proofs, that Philip Burrowes was named as sole executor, and Messrs. Bulkley (W. H.) and McCahill (John) were the subscribing witnesses. It also appeared that McCahill was sworn as a witness on the probate of such will; that Bulkley was then deceased, and his handwriting had been proved by a witness (Brown.) On the trial in this case, McCahill was sworn, who testified that he knew both Philip Burrowes and Theodore B. Tallmadge in their lifetime, that he had witnessed a will of Tallmadge, and was examined in the surrogate's office to prove it; and that Bulkley was the other subscribing witness, but was dead at the time of trial He also testified as to what took place on the execution of the will. Prom his testimony it appeared that all the requisite formalities had been pursued.- He also testified, that he remembered some of the provisions of the will which he witnessed, and mentioned those which he remembered. On referring to the copy will offered in evidence, provisions, substantially like those which the witness said he remembered to have been in the will which he witnessed, were found therein. On the cross-examination of McCahill he testified, among other things, as follows : “ Tallmadge’s mind was sound at the time he executed the will. * * He was under no restraint or compulsion when he executed the will, to my knowledge ; he was a man that drank, and sometimes got pretty well over; when not under the influence of liquor, he was very competent to attend to his own business, but he was not in business then; he was competent to take care of himself; he used to get drunk frequently; it was after he left the office, that he would indulge in these habits; at the time he executed this will, he was not under the influence of liquor; he presented no appearance of being under the influence of liquor that I recollect; it was in the fore*174noon; he had not then taken any thing that I was aware of. * * I do not think Mr. Tallmadge said any thing at the time the will was executed, he merely assented by nodding his head. I think Burrowes (the executor) brought Tallmadge into the office with the will. The will was not read to Mr. Tallmadge in my presence at the time of execution, to my recollection, nor was it read by him in my presence, that I recollect. Mr. Tallmadge always wore spectacles, and then did not see very well. Mr. Burrowes was Mr. Tallmadge’s man of business, his attorney and agent, and attended to his business; so far as I know he had the whole control of Mr. Tallmadge’s property. I think Burrowes collected the income of Tallmadge’s estate. He paid over to Mr. Tallmadge the money he got. Mr. Burrowes paid the money over sparingly; as a general thing, I think Burrowes preferred not to give Tallmadge money. I have already stated the habits of Mr. Tallmadge were intemperate ; I have seen him at the office pretty full, what might be called tipsy, but not often.” William McMurray, a witness examined for the defense, testified that he had known Mr. Tallmadge from about 1837, except when he was out of the city in Europe; that he could not state particularly what his general capacity was in 1839, in regard to that precise period; and also as follows: “During the wholé period of time when I was in the office of Tallmadge (the testator’s uncle) & Bulkley, I never saw any thing about him, but what indicated the full average of capacity; I did not regard him as deficient. He was reputed to be close about money matters by those about the office; I never had any money dealings with him. I do not think I ever saw him drunk; once I saw him when he had just recovered from a fit of drunkenness, as I could reasonably suppose; I may have seen him, perhaps, a little fuddled ; when he came to the office of Tallmadge & Bulkley, I think he was particularly careful to come there sober, because James Tallmadge was his uncle. I saw him last, *175within a couple of weeks of his death, in a carriage in which I took him to the boat that left this city for Hudson.” The plaintiffs called, as a witness, Joseph Weeks, who testified that he knew Mr. Tallmadge at Hempstead, where he resided in the year 1839, and was on relations of social intimacy with him, and as follows: “Previous to his leaving Hempstead in 1839, I considered his habits rather loose; he was accustomed to drink; he drank rather to excess at times, and once I saw him badly intoxicated. I saw Burrowes in company with Tallmadge at Hempstead frequently; he visited there; he appeared to be the only friend he had. I saw him perhaps two or three times a week for about three years; in that time I saw him drunk once and no more; on that occasion he was so drunk they carried him out to put him into the sleigh; he was not at my house; Mrs. Tallmadge was there.” Also, Henry J. Genet, who. testified that he was a cousin of the testator; that testator’s habits were not good during the year 1839; at and prior to April 13, 1839, his habits were bad; also as follows: “ I have seen him intoxicated frequently to such an extent that he did not know what he was doing; he was addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors prior to April 13, 1839, for several years ; I think it was very seldom I met him prior to April 13, 1839, back as far as I know, but that he was under the influence of liquor more or less ; I met him, certainly,' at Mr. Burrowes’ office, he was under the influence of liquor, somewhat, at that time; he was there to transact business; I did not see any transacted. He showed that he had got too much liquor; out of his mind in a measure; he moved about, he was not-dead drunk.” Mr. Tallmadge died in January, 1841, at the age of twenty-eight; the will was executed in April, 1839. At the time of the making the will there were living the plaintiffs, who were the infant children of the decedent, a sister, a brother, and a son of a deceased brother, all living at the time of his death. *176The defendants then read the following documentary evidence, to wit: 1. A deed, (conveying the locus in quo,) made by Philip Burrowes, sole executor of the last will and testament of Theodore B. Tallmadge, to Thomas O’Reilly, dated May 19, 1845, (acknowledged the same day,.and recorded May 23, 1845,) for the consideration of $10,000. A mortgage back of the same premises from O’Reilly to Burrowes, as executor, dated May 19, 1845, (acknowledged same day, and recorded May 23, 1845,) for $5500. Another mortgage back from O’Reilly to Burrowes, as executor, for $3500; making together, $9000. 2. An assignment of the first mortgage, made by Burrowes to Thomas O’Reilly, James Foster and others, executors of James Foster, deceased, dated, acknowledged and recorded the same day as the mortgage. 3. A warranty deed, made by Philip Burrowes and wife to John Harrison, for the consideration of $20,000, dated July 31, 1851, (acknowledged May 1, and recorded May 11, 1852,) conveying the two lots in question with two others. 4. A deed from Thomas O’Reilly to John Harrison, for the consideration of $22,000, dated April 6,1855, (acknowledged same day and recorded April 7,1855,) conveying the four lots conveyed by the deed from Burrowes to Harrison, (subject to the above two mortgages made by O’Reilly to Burrowes, as executor,) and two other lots, amounting im all to $10,500. The plaintiffs examined Thomas O’Reilly as to the transaction resulting in the conveyance to him of the lots in question. The body of the alleged will of Tallmadge was in the following words: “ I, Theodore B. Tallmadge, of Hempstead, in the county of Queens, state of New York, do make this my last will and testament, hereby revoking all other wills by me at any time made; I give and bequeath unto my dear-friend *177Philip Burrowes, the sum of five thousand dollars, in remembrance of his affectionate, and faithful friendship towards me for many years. I give and bequeath unto my dear wife Mary Ann, for and during her natural life, and as her own exclusive and separate estate and property, one-half part, share or portion of the interest, income, rents or profits of all my estate and property of which I shall die seised, possessed of or entitled to, the same to be inalienable by my said wife, and to be regulated, collected, and paid to her by my executor, upon her own sole and separate receipt only; and to be in lieu and bar of all dower or other claims to my estate. I direct the remaining one half, part, share or proportion of the interest, income, rent and profits of all my said estate and property, to be collected, regulated and appropriated by my executor in his best judgment and discretion to and for the education, support, advancement, use and benefit of my dear daughter, Laura E. Tallmadge, until she shall attain the age of twenty-one years, and when she shall attain this age, then that my executor pay over and account to my said daughter for the accumulation of said interest, income, rents and profits of said moiety as aforesaid. On my said daughter, Laura E. Tallmadge, attaining the said age of twenty-one years, then I give, devise and bequeath unto my said daughter all the rest, residue and remainder of all my estate, real and personal and of every kind whatsoever; to hold to her, her heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, forever; it being my will and intention that she shall thereupon become entitled to and seised of one moiety of all my said estate and property absolutely, and that she shall also become entitled to the other moiety thereof; but subject to the life estate of her mother and to the trusts in respect thereof as above expressed. In case I shall have any other child or children by my said wife, living at my decease, then I desire that said child or children shall equally participate with my said daughter, Laura E. Tallmadge, in the provisions hereinbefore made for her, and *178that in such case my said wife shall only have a life estate as above provided in the same proportions as each child, instead of a full moiety, as above given. In case my said daughter, Laura E. and all other of my said child or children by my said wife, if any there shall be, shall die before attaining the age of twenty-one years, then I give, devise and bequeath the estate and property herein given to my said child or children, and all other my estate and property, absolutely unto the said Philip Burrowes, as my best and dearest friend, forever, but subject however to the provisions of my said wife during her life as aforesaid, and to a legacy of tw enty-five hundred dollars each, to my nephews, George Clinton Tallmadge and Charles William Tallmadge, if then living. I do hereby appoint the said Philip Burrowes, executor of this my will, and guardian of the person and estate of my dear daughter, Laura E., and of any other future child or children of mine as aforesaid, during minority, in the fullest confidence that he will faithfully and affectionately perform the trusts hereby confided to him as a kind and faithful friend. And for the purpose of enabling my said executor to carry into full effect the intent and provisions of this my will, I do hereby convey and vest in him all my said estate and property of every kind, with full power and authority to sell, convey, assign, collect, satisfy, discharge, invest and reinvest the same and the proceeds thereof, and every part thereof, in his best judgment and discretion for the benefit of my said wife, child or children, as aforesaid. And lastly, in addition to the income hereinbefore provided for my said wife during her life, as aforesaid, I also give and bequeath to my said dear wife all my household furniture, horses and carriages of every kind, for her own absolute use and benefit forever.” A verdict was taken for the defendants, subject, to the exceptions of the plaintiffs, and such exceptions were ordered to be heard in the first place at the general term. *179G. W. Lord, for the plaintiffs.

I. Mr. Tallmadge, at, and immediately previous to, the time of his death, was an inhabitant either of (Hudson) Columbia, or of (Hempstead) Queens county; in neither case had the surrogate of the city and county of Hew York any jurisdiction in reference to the probate of said alleged will. (3 R. S. 5th ed. p. 362, § 2. Fiske v. Anderson, 33 Barb. 71 Bloom v. Burdick, 1 Hill, 134.)

n. Even if the alleged testator had been an inhabitant of the city and county of Hew York, his proceedings were void.

1. The petition was sworn to before a commissioner of deeds. This was not a compliance with the statute which requires the surrogate to “ ascertain by satisfactory evidence,” the facts on which he is authorized to issue his citation. (3 R. S. 5th ed. p. 146, § 50; p. 474, §. 38. Stanton v. Ellis, 16 Barb. 322.)

2. The citations issued were riot served on the special guardian of the infants. This is absolutely required by statute, and proof of that fact must be taken, before the surrogate is authorized to proceed. (3 R. S. 5th ed. p. 147, §§ 53, 55, 56. Corwin v. Merritt, 3 Barb. 341.) The guardian could not confer jurisdiction by a voluntary appearance, nor could the statement of that fact in the record cure the defect. (Dakin v. Demming, 6 Paige, 95. Coffin v. Tracy, 3 Cai. 129. Litchfield v. Burwell, 5 How. Pr. 341. Sibley v. Waffle, 16 N. Y. Rep. 189.)

III. The probate of the surrogate of the city and county of Hew York being void, for the reasons before stated, the record was improperly received in evidence.

IV. The deeds executed by Burrowes were void and conveyed no title.

1. A person merely named as an executor in a will cannot exercise any power conferred by it (except to pay funeral charges, &c.) until letters testamentary have been issued by the surrogate authorized by law to take the proof of the same. (3 R. S. 5th ed. p. 156, § 16. Thomas v. Cameron, 16 Wend. *180579. Dayton on Sur. 233. Willard on Executors, 146.) And letters testamentary cannot be granted until the will has been properly proved. (R. S. p. 154, §§ 1, 2.) The probate of the will is, therefore, a condition precedent to the exercise of any power conferred by it, except to pay debts and to preserve the estate. (Taylor v. Morris, 1 Comst. 341.) That such is the true construction of the statute further appears by section 66, (p. 197,) which provides that if one executor neglects- to qualify, a power of sale is to be exercised by those who do qualify. These statutory provisions clearly show, that no testator can convey real estate as the donee of a power, until the will is proved and letters testamentary are issued to him. Even before the Eevised Statutes an executor could not convey as the donee of a power, where the power (as in this case) was given to him virtute officii. (Dominick v. Michael, 4 Sandf. 400.)

2. Even if Burrowes had proved the will, he could not convey a valid title to the premises in question, because the trusts attempted to be created by the alleged will were contrary to law, and therefore illegal and void, (a.) As to the share of the estate given to the widow, the trust was void, inasmuch as the absolute power of alienation was suspended for more than two lives in being at the creation of the estate, which was the death of the testator. (3 R. S. 5th ed. p. 75, § 1; p. 11, § 15.) The power of alienation was suspended, during the life of the widow and the minority of two children ; in construing this statute, each minority is counted as a life, (Hawley v. James, 16 Wend. 61,) here the power of alienation was suspended, for three lives in being, at the time of the testator’s death. If there is a possibility of the limitation extending beyond the lives of any two of them, it is void. (Hawley v. James, 16 Wend. 61. Vail v. Vail, 7 Barb. 236. Tayloe v. Gould, 10 id. 398; 20 Wend. 564. Van Vechten v. Van Veghten, 8 Paige, 104. Browns v. Evans, 34 Barb. 594. Jennings v. Jennings, 7 N. Y. Rep. 547.) (b.) The trust in favor of the children, was also void for the reason that the accumulation of the rents and profits

*181was not exclusively for the benefit of minors. (3 R. S. 13, § 37.) Upon the death of the children, under age, Burrowes, an adult, would take the accumulated fund. A trust to accumulate, for the benefit of minors, whose right to the accumulated fund is entirely contingent—is void. In this ease, the right of the children to the fund, was contingent upon their arriving of age. (Harris v. Clark, 3 Seld. 242, 257. Haxtun v. Corse, 2 Barb. Ch. 506, 518. Kilpatrick v. Johnson, 15 N. Y. Rep. 322.) An implied direction to accumulate, is equally void, with an express direction. (Vail v. Vail, 4 Paige, 317. Hawley v. James, 5 id. 318, 481.)

3. The estate vested in the heirs at law absolutely. The trusts being void, and the power of sale having been given solely to carry them out, such power was void. (Persons v. Snook, 40 Barb. 146; 4 Hill, 492.) If either trust was void, the whole estate descended to the heirs at law. The two trusts constituted a general scheme of the testator, and cannot be separated. (Lorillard v. Costar, 5 Paige, 172. S. C. 14 Wend. 265. Field v. Field, 4 Sandf. Ch. 528.) If they could, and one be valid and the other invalid, the portion of the estate, embraced in the void trust, descends to the heirs at law. As to that part, the testator is to be regarded as having died intestate; and the conveyance by Burrowes was inoperative as to that portion, inasmuch as he was only empowered to sell the estate devised by the will, and not that part undevised.

V. The will itself was invalid and void, for undue influence exercised by Burrowes in procuring it.

1. He drew the alleged will (under which he claimed the right to sell and convey the premises in question) when he was the confidential friend and adviser of Mr. Tallmadge, and had the entire control and management of his estate. He was not only a legatee under the will, but was also the ultimate beneficiary of the whole estate upon the death of the children under age. These facts constitute a legal presumption of undue influence.' (Lansing v. Russell, 13 Barb. 510. Lakev. Raney, 33 id. 49.)

*1822. Under these circumstances, "before the will could be sustained, it must be shown either that the testator gave instructions to have it drawn, or that he knew the contents of the will. Proof of the factum, merely, is not sufficient. (Crispell v. Dubois, 4 Barb. 393. Burritt v. Silliman, 16 id. 199. Vreeland v. McClelland, 1 Bradf. 393.) Ho such proof was given, either before the surrogate or upon the trial in the court below. Even if the facts proved did not constitute a legal presumption of undue influence, the question should have been submitted to the jury as one of fact.

VI. The defendants cannot rely on the bona fides of their purchase as a defense.

1. If Burrowes had no authority to sell and convey, then any person purchasing from him with notice (express or implied) of the trust, became himself a trustee, notwithstanding the consideration he paid, and cannot set up an adverse title as against the cestui que trust. (10 John. 495. 1 John. Ch. 566. 4 id. 136. 3 Sandf. Ch. 592.)

2. The question whether the deed from Burrowes to O’Eeilly was a bona fide conveyance with intent to pass the title, or a mere scheme to enable Burrowes to raise money by mortgage, should have been submitted to the jury.

3. The conveyance to O’Eeilly passed no title, as the deed was without consideration and was never delivered. Such a conveyance was not a valid execution of the power contained in the will.

4. The conveyance from Burrowes to Harrison passed no title, except such as Burrowes had individually; nor was such conveyance a valid execution of the power of sale.

5. Harrison was notified before he paid the mortgages that the title would be contested.

VII. The proof of the will upon the trial in the court below, as a lost will, could not have a retro-active effect, so as to give validity to a conveyance executed before the will Was proved. Letters testamentary must be issued to the executor by the court or officer before whom the will is *183proved before he can sell or dispose of any part of the estate.

VIH. The court below erred in refusing to charge the jury, as requested by the plaintiffs’ counsel. And also, in refusing to submit to the jury as questions of fact the questions presented by the plaintiffs’ counsel.

H. A. Oram, for the defendants.

I. The plaintiffs’ claim in this action is founded on merely formal and technical matter, without any semblance of merit or justice, and has been already passed on adversely to the plaintiffs by two other courts. (Morrell v. Dennison, 8 Abb. 401. Bolton v. Brewster, 32 Barb. 389.) Those decisions dispose of all the real questions raised in this case. H. The probate was valid; being the judgment of a court having jurisdiction of the matter. (Allen v. Dundas, 3 T. R. 125-129, 132.)

I. The surrogate upon the application to him for probate had jurisdiction, and was bound to determine every question involved in such application for probate; of which the question whether the decedent at or immediately previous to his death, was an inhabitant of the county of Hew York, was one. His decision of that question was as conclusive as if on appeal it had been affirmed in the Court of Appeals.

2. The surrogate’s court is not an inferior court acting in derogation of the common law, or of the jurisdiction of common law courts, and therefore the rule as to inferior courts does not apply to it. This is deducible 1st. From legal principles; 2d. Express adjudication; 3d. The uniform practice of the courts and practitioners; and 4th. Considerations of public policy and the inconvenience and injustice of a contrary doctrine. (1.) Upon general principles, (a.) It is a court of general, original, and exclusive- though peculiar jurisdiction. Ho other court has original jurisdiction of these matters, therefore- quoad these causes it is a superior court. (5.) Its jurisdiction is not in derogation of the common law, or of any common law court, and *184therefore need not be averred, as the jurisdiction of an inferior court, which interferes with the jurisdiction of a superior court, must be. There is no presumption against its jurisdiction, or in favor of that of a superior court to be overcome by averment or proof, (c.) It stands upon the same ground and is supported by the same reason, as that of a superior common law court. (Gelston v. Hoyt, 3 Wheat. 315.) (2.) Upon authority. There may be dicta to a contrary effect in eases where the question was not carefully considered, or even formally examined; but in the following cases the question was carefully and deliberately examined and settled by an express decision. (Obert v. Hammell, 3 Harr. 73, 78-81. See also Raborg v. Hammond, 2 Har. & Gill, 42, 49, 50; Holcomb v. Phelps, 16 Conn. Rep. 127; McPherson v. Cunliffe, 11 Sergt. & Rawl. 422.) (3.) Uniform practice sustains this conclusion, (a.) If this court were an inferior court, it would be necessary in every case where probate or letters of administration are set up, such as every action by an administrator or executor to foreclose a mortgage given to the decedent, or to recover money due to him, to aver and prove the facts on which the jurisdiction of the surrogate depended. (Wyman v. Mitchell, 1 Cowen, 316. Morgan v. Dyer, 10 John. 161, 163. Ladbrohe v. James, Willes, 199. Sollers v. Lawrence, Id. 199.) But it has never been so considered necessary, nor has it ever been done. (Isherwood v. Oldknow, 3 Maule. Sel. 396, 397. Ram on Judg. 12, 13, 62, 65. Earl of Buckinghamshire v. Drury, 2 Eden, 64, 74. Wilm. Opin. 218, 219, 226. Smith v. Doe, d. Jersey, 2 Brod. & Bing. 574, 575, 599, 611, 612. Howard v. Duncan, 1 Turn. Russ. 81, 86, 87. Candler v. Candler, Jacob. 232. Stanley v. Leigh, 2 P. Will. 690.) (b) Even if it could be shown that this practice was originally erroneous, it should now be upheld pursuant to the maxim communis error facit jus. (Virely v. Gunstone, Hob. 83, Parkhurst v. Smith, Wittes, 339, 4 Co. Ins. 240. Ram on Judg. 14, 15. Nay’s Maxims, maxim 27.) (4.) The doctrine is proved by considerations of public policy, and of the inconvenience and *185injustice of a contrary rule. (Raborg v. Hammond, 2 Har. & Grill, 42, 49, 50.) («.) To require parties who rely upon letters of administration or letters testamentary to prove the facts on which the jurisdiction of the surrogate rests, would he always inconvenient, often unjust, sometimes impossible. In most cases it would be impracticable after a lapse of years. (b.) There is no reason for requiring it. The surrogate is as competent to determine such a question as any other which can come before him, and not only competent, but required to pass upon the question. His decision of it, like that upon any other question, can be reviewed, and if erroneous, reversed on appeal, but until so reversed, it is as conclusive as that of the appellate court. If the Court of Appeals on such an appeal, should decide that the surrogate had jurisdiction, would not that judgment be conclusive, or must the evidence be adduced and the fact be tried over in every case where the surrogate’s decree is relied on ? (e.) Must a party, whose title depends upon it, lose his property, if another court comes to a different conclusion from the surrogate’s, or he cannot after a lapse of years, produce the evidence which had been given before the surrogate ? Is it proper, that an opportunity should thus be afforded for conflicting decisions between courts, or that the decision of one court should thus have greater effect or be more conclusive than that of another court, no less competent, and probably better qualified to decide it, from having heard the case before evidence was lost, and when the memory of witnesses was more fresh, accurate, and reliable? Interest reipublioce ut sit finis litium. (d.) The decision of the surrogate upon this question ought, therefore, from considerations of public policy, of convenience, and of justice, to be conclusive.

3. It is no valid objection to the doctrine, that a surrogate’s court is a local or limited court. The court of common pleas is equally local; yet it is well settled that it is not an inferior court. (Foot v. Stevens, 17 Wend. 483. And see Peacock v. Bell, 1 Saund. 73.) A Circuit Court of the United *186States is a local court, and moreover, in cases between citizens of different states, &c. its jurisdiction of a case depends upon one of the parties being a citizen of the state and the other being a citizen of another state, or an alien, yet it is not an inferior court, and it can determine the question, whether' the fact exists on which its jurisdiction of a case depends ; and its decision of that question is conclusive, until duly reversed in the appellate court. (Erwin v. Lowry, 7 How. U. S. 172.) There is no reason why a surrogate’s decision of the question on which his jurisdiction depends, should not be equally conclusive.

4. It is no objection that the surrogate’s court is a statutory court. (Doe, dem. Obert v. Hammell, 3 Harr. 73.) As it is so in no other sense than that the particular officer who is to exercise jurisdiction, is designated by statute, (a.) The jurisdiction itself is not new, and it is not created by statute. It is as old as the common law. (Doe, dem. Obert v. Hammond, ubi sup.) (b.) The jurisdiction, as to the granting letters testamentary and letters of administration, is quite different from the jurisdiction specially conferred by statute, to order the sale of real estate, &c. The latter is new and statutory. But, even as to that jurisdiction, the judgment or decree of the surrogate is conclusive. (Grignon’s Lessee V. Astor, 2 How. U. S. 319. Erwin v. Lowry, 7 id. 172. Seargeant v. State Bank of Indiana, 12 id. 385. Dyekman v. Mayor of New York, 1 Seld. 434, 436, 440, 443.)

HI. The grant of letters testamentary, therefore, was conclusive evidence of the will; being a judgment of a court of general, original and exclusive jurisdiction, it cannot be questioned in this suit. It cannot be impeached by averring that there was no evidence that the deceased, at or immediately previous to his decease, was an inhabitant of the county of Hew York, or, by affirmative proof, that he was not such an inhabitant; that was a question to be decided by the surrogate’s court, and his judgment is conclusive; it cannot be tried over again every time the probate is produced in a court. Judgments of courts of general jurisdic*187tion, are conclusive This is a general rule, applicable to all such judgments, and especially to those of peculiar and exclusive jurisdiction. There are peculiar reasons for the application of this rule to surrogate’s courts, because their mode of proceedings, and their rules of evidence are not according to the common law; but are founded upon the civil and canon law, of which, this court in a case coming up before it as a case of original jurisdiction, can take judicial notice.

3. If the surrogate’s court, however, were an inferior court, the- probate would, nevertheless, be conclusive, (a.) An inferior court may determine whether the fact on which its jurisdiction depends, exists or not, and when it is authorized and competent to • determine that question, its decision is conclusive until duly reversed. (Brittain v. Kinnaird, 1 Brod. & Bing. 432. S. C. 4 Moore, 50. State v. Scott, 1 Bailey’s Law R. 294. Grignon’s Lessee v. Astor, 2 How. U. S. Rep. 319. Sergeant v. State of Indiana, 12 id. 385. 2 Cowen & Hill, 1016, 1017.) (6.) In this case, moreover, there was evidence clearly tending to prove the habitancy of the decedent in this county; the competency of the evidence and its sufficiency were matters for the determination of the surrogate. If his decision were erroneous, it could only be corrected on appeal; until reversed it was conclusive. The allegation in Mr. Burrowes’ petition of his habitancy, verified by his oath, was competent legal evidence of the fact; (Dyckman v. Mayor, &c. of New York, 1 Seld. 438, 443, 444;) tt gave the surrogate per se jurisdiction. [Id.)

4. The widow and phildren of the decedent were duly made parties to the proceedings before the surrogate. (.a) The process was served on the widow; that made her a party. (b.) There was a guardian duly appointed for the infant children, who were under fourteen years of age, and he appeared. That made them parties. (Laws of 1837, ch. 460, §§ 5-7. And see Keeney v. Whitmarsh, 16 Barb. 141.) They are, therefore, bound by the judgment and decree of *188the surrogate, upon the ground that all the parties to a suit are bound by the judgment. On this ground also the probate is competent, and sufficient evidence of the will.

5. The probate was valid. (I.) The conclusiveness of a decree of a court like the surrogate’s, on the jurisdictional fact of the decedent’s having been an inhabitant of this county, has after an elaborate discussion, by solemn decision been expressly adjudged. (Roborg v. Hammond, 2 Har. § Gr. 42.) (2.) But, if necessary to prove affirmatively that the surrogate of'New York had jurisdiction to grant probate, there was sufficient evidence for that purpose in this case, (a.) The decedent was before, and at the time of his death, the owner of lands in that county; his constituted him legally an inhabitant of this county. (2 Co. Ins. 702. The King v. Barwick, 7 Term Rep. 35.) This was an established rule and doctrine of law at the time when the statute was passed, and it must be presumed to have been known to, and within the intent and purpose of the legislature in the enactment of that statute. (6.) If the ownership of real estate in this county did not constitute him an inhabitant of that county, the express terms of the statute gave the surrogate of that county jurisdiction of the case, as no other surrogate had at that time “gained” jurisdiction of it. (Laws of 1837, p. 524,’ eh. 460, § 1, subd. 5.) There is meaning and force in the word “gained.” Two or more'surrogates may “have” concurrent jurisdiction, but the one to whom application for probate is first made, thereby “ gains ” jurisdiction of the particular case. This is a familiar rule of law. (Taylor v. Caryll, 20 How. U. S. 607, 608.) The legislature intended, that if a testator by his will devised lands of which he was seised in any county of the state, the surrogate of that county should have authority to grant probate, unless some other surrogate had previously “ gained jurisdiction ” of the case by an application for probate. This is the true construction, otherwise the word “ gained ” would never have been *189inserted. It would be altogether superfluous and nugatory, and worse than unmeaning—it would be calculated to mislead. If this construction were upon the face of this clause of the statute doubtful, all doubts would be removed by a reference to another provision of the statute, (2 R. S. 73, §§ 24, 25,) which is an express declaration of the meaning and intention of the legislature, and which, being in pari materia, is to be referred to, if necessary, to explain their language. (King qui tam v. Smith, 4 T. R. 414, 419. Dwarris on Stat. 9 Law Lib. 699-701.)

IH. If the probate is invalid and should be disregarded, there is sufficient evidence to warrant the direction of the court, given in this case to the jury.

1. Burrowes was. either the devisee of an estate or the donee of a power, and in either event, he might exercise the power or convey the estate, although he did not qualify as executor. (Conklin v. Egerton, 21 Wend. 430. Newton v. Bronson, 3 Kern. 587. Powell, on Devises, 238. Hill on Trustees, 353. 11 East, 288.)

2. The execution of the will and its contents, were sufficiently proved, without resorting to the probate. The evidence on this head was sufficient, even under the provisions of the statute as to lost wills, but that statute does not apply, and the proof of the execution of the will and of its contents was sufficient at common law. (Orser v. Orser, 24 N Y. Rep. 51.)

3. The surrogate’s copy of the will was sufficient evidence of the contents, even if the probate was. invalid. (Jackson v. Lucett, 2 Caines, 365. Jackson v. Rice, 3 Wend. 180.) A witness (McCahill) sufficiently proved the contents of the will.

IV. In this action of ejectment, it was enough to have proved a legal, conveyance by the trustee; it cannot be impeached here. But not only was there a failure to impeach either of the two conveyances, but they were shown to be bona fide for a valuable consideration paid. The acknowledgment of the receipt of the purchase money in the con*190veyances, is prima facie evidence of a bona fide purchase, (Wood v. Chapin, 3 Kern. 509;) but actual payment was proved, in addition, affirmatively.

Y. Burrowes’ deed to Harrison, if material, although in his individual right, was sufficient to defeat the action, (3 R. S. 28, § 144, 5th ed:) But the executor’s deed to O’Reilly, was a conclusive bar.

In addition to' the objection to the introduction of the record of the surrogate on the trial, various other points were raised which are properly presented for the determination of the general term, and will appear in the course of this opinion, but the objections to the introduction of the records from the surrogate’s office will be first disposed of.

Although the statute neither requires the presentation of a petition to a surrogate, nor that the surrogate shall take proof of or ascertain in what county the testator died, yet there can be no doubt that he has power to ascertain whether the facts upon which his jurisdiction rests, exist or not; and if he requires such facts to be shown by a verified petition as a foundation for the issuance of a citation, the petition becomes a part of the record, and the statement of jurisdictional matters therein, is a statement of such matters in, and on the face of, the record, and is prima facie evidence of their existence, although not conclusive, as will hereafter appear. The objection, then, that the record did not show jurisdiction of the subject matter, although, perhaps good when taken, yet was cured when the petition was read in evidence. As the record shows jurisdiction of the subject matter on its face, it was unnecessary to prove the facts conferring it, aliunde; the second objection was, therefore, not good. The third objection, to wit, that the record showed . on its face, want of jurisdiction over the persons of the plaintiffs, because there was no proof of the service of a citation on their special guardian, was untenable, since the record *191shows that the special guardian appeared on the taking proof of the execution of the will.

There is no statutory provision requiring the jurisdiction of a surrogate, who has admitted a will to probate to be proved aliunde before his record can be read in evidence. The judgment of the surrogate’s court, admitting a will to probate, is the authority for its record under the statute. If, then, the record of the judgment shows jurisdiction on its face, the authority for making the record of the will is established prima facie, and under the provisions of the statute it becomes admissible in evidence. As such jurisdiction was shown on the face of the record, in this case, the fourth objection was properly overruled.

It is not shown in’ what respect the proof before the surrogate was insufficient to entitle the will to be admitted to probate. Upon a close scrutiny of the proofs adduced, we are unable to discover any insufficiency; the last objection is, consequently, not sustainable.

With reference to the objections to the reception in evidence of the petition, as has been before remarked, there is no provision of the statute requiring a petition. The statute provides that the executor, devisee, or legatee named in any will, or any person interested in the estate, may have such will proved before the proper surrogate, and then that “ on application to the surrogate he shall ascertain, by satisfactory evidence, the following factsthe facts so to be ascertained are simply the names and residences of the persons who are to be notified to attend the probate. (Laws of 1837, p. 524.) A proceeding before a court or a magistrate sitting in a judicial capacity must always be initiated by some proceeding on behalf of a party in interest. If there is no mode in which the proceeding is to be initiated pointed out by statute^ the court or magistrate must prescribe such mode. The statute under consideration does not prescribe how the application is to be made; therefore, immediately after its passage, the ordinary mode used for setting a court in motion, when neither an action at law or a suit in equity; *192was commenced, was adopted, viz. by petition verified before a proper officer. Such petition becomes the foundation of the whole proceeding, the same as a petition to the Court of Chancery for the exercise of any part of its jurisdiction, not required to be invoked by bill; as the bill in an equity suit, as the declaration in an action at law (commenced by declaration.) As such petition, bill and declaration form a part of the record, so also does the petition to the surrogate; thus, then, the statement of jurisdictional facts in the petition to the surrogate became a recital of their existence on the face of the record, the same as in the ease of a petition to' a Court of Chancery, bill in equity, or declaration at law; being such a recital, they are prima facie evidence in support of jurisdiction, whenever that is attacked collaterally. This is the effect given by law to such a recital in the event of such attack.

A point was made as to the verification of the petition not being before the surrogate, but before a commissioner of deeds. A commissioner of deeds is an officer authorized to administer oaths in all cases where no special provision-is made by law. There being no special provision requiring petitions of the character of the one in question to be sworn to before the surrogate or by officers other than a commissioner of deeds, it was properly verified before such commissioner.

To prevent misapprehension, it will be well distinctly to state that it is not intended to hold that the presentation of a petition containing proper allegations of itself gives the surrogate jurisdiction, but simply that the statements in such petition are prima facie evidence of jurisdictional facts, when the jurisdiction of the surrogate is attacked collaterally.

Having disposed of these objections, we will-now proceed to the more important points raised on the argument. The first point raised is that the plaintiffs having clearly shown that the decedent at the time of his death, and immediately prior thereto, was an inhabitant of Columbia county, the surrogate of New York county had no jurisdiction to *193admit Ms will to probate, although he died seized of real estate, situate in the county of New York. That point is well taken. Section 1 of chapter 430 of the laws of 1837, enacts that the surrogate of each county shall have jurisdiction, exclusive of every other surrogate (within the county for which he may be appointed) to take the proof of the last wills and testaments of all deceased persons in four cases, three of which provide for the nomresidence of the decedent in the state. They are as follows:

1st. Where, the testator, at or immediately previous to his death, should be an inhabitant of the county of such surrogate, in whatever place such death might happen.
2d. Where the testator, not being an inhabitant of this state, should die in the county of such surrogate, leaving assets therein.
3d. Where the testator, not being an inhabitant of this state, should die out of the state, leaving assets therein.
4th. Where a testator, not being an inhabitant of this state, should die out of the state, not leaving assets therein, but assets of such testator should thereafter come into the county of such surrogate.
5th. Where no surrogate has gained jurisdiction under either of the preceding clauses, and any real, estate devised by the testator should be situate in the county of such surrogate.

Were it not for the use of the word “ gained ” in the fifth of such clauses, the surrogate of Columbia would unquestionably have had exclusive jurisdiction to take the proof of the will in question; it is, however, insisted that by force of that word, any surrogate, in whose county real estate devised by a will is situate, by issuing the necessary citations, ousts all other surrogates of any jurisdiction, so far as proof of such will is concerned, which they otherwise might have had under any of the preceding clauses. The argument is that the phrase “gained jurisdiction,” means, and is to be read, as if it were “ obtained jurisdiction by proceedings having been taken before him to prove the will of the testator.” *194It is obvious that the jurisdiction of each surrogate over the proof of wills is limited to those cases in which it is given to him by this section. Thus, if a testator, in whose will there is no devise of real estate, he not being an inhabitant of the state, dies out of the state, leaving assets in the county of Ulster alone, there can be no question but that the surrogate of Ulster has exclusive jurisdiction under the third enumerating clause. It necessarily follows that the jurisdiction of any particular surrogate depends on the concurrence of those events, on whose concurrence the statute gives him jurisdiction. Before their happening and such concurrence he has no jurisdiction whatever. Upon such happening and concurrence he immediately gains jurisdiction, and cannot thereafter be divested of it. I employ the word “gain,” for where the jurisdiction depends on the taking place of some event, then on such event occurring, a jurisdiction which did not before exist may be said to be obtained, got, acquired or gained; those words used in this connection are synonymous.

In this view the meaning of the word “gained,” in the fifth clause, is clear and unambiguous. It refers to surrogates getting jurisdiction over the subject matter of the proof of a particular will, by the happening and concurrence of some of the events mentioned in the preceding clauses. There is, therefore, no necessity for the. purpose of clearing up any ambiguity, to interpolate in the fifth clause after the word jurisdiction, the words “ by the issuing of proper citations.” The interpolation of those words, which are generally used in speaking of obtaining jurisdiction over the person, would be apt to defeat the intent of the statute, by making the jurisdiction given by the fifth clause depend on the omission of any other surrogate to obtain jurisdiction, over the persons of those who are to be cited, instead of over the subject matter. The effect of such interpolation, too, would be to require one of a like kind in each of the other clauses, so that the statute, instead of giving by them to the various surrogates exclusive jurisdic*195tion in the specified cases, would provide that no surrogate should have exclusive jurisdiction when the will should devise real estate, unless he should be the first surrogate before whom proceedings to prove the will should have been taken. As before observed, there is no such uncertainty in the intent of the legislature, created by the use of the word “gain” nor is there any such obscurity or ambiguity in the language employed to convey such intent, as to justify such extensive interpolations.

The term “gaining jurisdiction ” has been applied to cases where two courts have concurrent jurisdiction over the subject matter of the cause or proceeding; when so applied it means “ gaining jurisdiction ” by proceedings had in one of the courts. In this class of cases, it sometimes occurs that a question arises, as to which court shall take and retain jurisdiction over the particular cause or proceeding. It is of course, necessary to adopt some rule on the subject in such eases, which is, that the court in which proceedings are first taken, takes and retains jurisdiction to the exclusion of the other. Therefore, in discussing the question, as to which of such two courts has gained jurisdiction to the exclusion of the other, the expression “ gained jurisdiction ” means, “ by proceedings first taken,” since that is the only way in which such jurisdiction can be obtained. But different surrogates have not concurrent jurisdiction over all the cases mentioned in the fifth clause. The term “gains jurisdiction,” used in the fifth clause, therefore, does not of necessity, (as is the case in questions arising between concurrent jurisdictions,) mean by proceedings being first taken before another surrogate; but its meaning must be such as the whole context of the section in which it is used calls for and what that is we have already discussed. Many cases may arise under the statute to which the doctrine as to gaining jurisdiction that obtains in the case of courts of concurrent jurisdiction may be applicable; thus, under the third clause, the testator might leave assets in every county; in which case every surrogate would have *196concurrent jurisdiction over the subject matter. The same, result might occur under the fourth, and also under the fifth clause. Ho provision is made for these cases of concurrent jurisdiction by the act of 1837, but it is highly probable that, when such a case arises, the above mentioned rule, relative to the gaining of' jurisdiction by one of two of concurrent jurisdiction over the same subject matter, will be held to be applicable, there being nothing in the statute to prevent such application in such a case. Cases of concurrent jurisdiction, arising under the statute relative to the granting of letters of administration, are provided for by the Revised Statutes. Section 23, article 2, title 2, chapter 6, part .2, of the Revised Statutes defines the jurisdiction of a surrogate in granting letters of administration. That section has four clauses, which correspond precisely with the first four clauses in section 1, of the act of 1837, except that the word “ intestate ” is used instead of “testator,” and also with the exception that, at the end of the third clause in that section of the Revised Statutes, the words “ and in no other county,” are added. That section of the Revised Statutes does not provide for cases where an intestate, not being an inhabitant of the state, dies out of the state, leaving assets in several counties, and under the fourth clause of that section, cases of concurrent jurisdiction might arise. To provide for cases not provided for in that section, and also for such cases of concurrent jurisdiction as might arise under the 4th clause, two other section's, (24 and 25,) were introduced in such second article. The effect of those sections, so far as they bear on cases of concurrent jurisdiction, is to give to the surrogate who shall first grant letters of administration sole and exclusive jurisdiction. This is but putting in statutory form a principle which has been established by judicial decisions as applicable to cases of concurrent jurisdiction. It is urged, however, that the act of 1837, and sections 24 and 25 of such second article are statutes in pari materia, and should be construed together; and being so construed, *197the provisions of these sections indicate the meaning to be attached to the words “ gained jurisdiction,” in clause 5, section 1, of the act of 1837. The argument is, that the legislature having by sections 24 and 25 declared in what manner a surrogate shall obtain jurisdiction of the subject matter, when they thereafter use the terms “gain jurisdiction ” they mean in the manner before pointed out. There might be much force in this argument, if the legislature had by those sections, (24 and 25,) undertaken to give a general definition of the phrase “gained jurisdiction,” or enacted that in all cases of intestacy, the surrogate who first granted letters of administration should be deemed to have acquired sole and exclusive jurisdiction; but these sections neither give such general definition, nor make such enactment. The enactment refers to but one class of cases, viz: those of concurrent jurisdiction in two or more surrogates. This concurrence of jurisdiction must'first exist, before the enactment can take effect. By no rule of construction can a statute which is designed to meet cases of concurrent jurisdiction after they have arisen, be so expounded as to operate in the first instance to create such concurrence; yet this is the only way in which those sections can be applied to the act of 1837, so as to benefit the plaintiff. For this purpose, it must first be held that they operate so to give concurrent jurisdiction to two or more surrogates, and then that they provide a means b.y which one of those surrogates can oust the other of such concurrent jurisdiction. As those sections in the Revised Statutes, where they were first enacted, were not intended to, and do not have, the effect of creating a concurrent jurisdiction, it is difficult to see how, by any rule of construction, or process of reasoning, such effect can be given to ’ them, when transplanted into a statute of a later date.

Upon this branch of the case, therefore, I have come to the conclusion, that the testator, having been at the time of, and immediately prior to his death, an inhabitant of Columbia county, the surrogate of New York county, was *198not by the statute Invested with jurisdiction to admit the will to probate.

The next question is, can the decree of the surrogate of Hew York county be questioned for "the want of such jurisdiction ?

It is now conceded, (at least in this state,) that want of jurisdiction will render void the judgment of any court, whether it be of superior or inferior, of general, limited, or local jurisdiction, or of record or not; and that the bare recital of jurisdictional facts in the record of a judgment of any court, whether superior or inferior, of general or limited jurisdiction, is not conclusive, but only prima fade evidence of the truth of the fact recited, and the party against whom a judgment is offered, is not by the bare fact of such recitals, estopped from showing by affirmative proof that they were untrue,- and thus render the judgment void for want of jurisdiction.

Judge Marcy, said, (Starbuck v. Murray, 5 Wend. 158,) “ Unless a court has jurisdiction, it can never make a record, which imports uncontrolable verity to the party over whom it has usurped jurisdiction, and he ought not therefore to be estopped by any allegations in that record, from proving any fact that goes to establish the truth of a plea alleging a want of jurisdiction.” Chancellor Walworth laid down the principle in Davis v. Packard, (6 Wend. 332,) that “.If the jurisdiction of the court is general or unlimited "both as to parties and subject matter, it will be presumed to have had jurisdiction of the cause, unless it appears affirmatively from the record or by the showing of the party, denying the jurisdiction of the court, that some special circumstances existed to oust the court of its jurisdiction in that particular case.” Judge Bronson declared in The People v. Cassels, (5 Hill, 165;) “ Ho court or officer ■ can acquire jurisdiction by the mere assertion of it, or by falsely alleging the existence of facts on which jurisdiction depends.” And again in Bloom v. Burdick, (1 Hill, 139,) it is said, “ It is a cardinal principle in the administration of *199justice that no man can be condemned, or divested of his rights, until he has had the opportunity of being heard. He must in some way be brought into court, and if judgment is rendered against him before that is done, the proceeding will be as utterly void as though the court had undertaken to act, when the subject matter was not within its cognizance. The distinction between superior and inferior courts is not of much importance in this particular case, for whenever it appears that there was a want of jurisdiction, the judgment will be void in whatever court it was rendered.” Judge Paige held in Hard v. Shipman, (6 Barb. 623, 624,) that “ The want of jurisdiction may always be set up against a judgment of á court, whether of general or of special and limited jurisdiction, whenever such judgment is sought to be enforced, or any benefit is claimed under it. To give any binding effect to a judgment, it is essential that the court should have jurisdiction both of the person and of the subject matter. If a court, whether of general or limited jurisdiction, undertakes to hold cognizance of a cause without having jurisdiction both of the person and subject matter, the proceedings are utterly void. The jurisdiction of a court, whether of general or limited jurisdiction, may be inquired into, although the record of the judgment states facts giving it jurisdiction. The record is never conclusive as to a recital or the statement of a jurisdictional fact; and the defendant is always at liberty to show a want of jurisdiction, although the record avers the contrary. No court or officer can acquire jurisdiction by the mere assertion of it, or by falsely alleging the existence of facts on which jurisdiction depends. If the court had no jurisdiction, it had no power to make a record; and the supposed record is not in truth a record. If not a record, it can not import absolute verity.” Similar remarks as-to the effect of a record, are to be found in 5 Wend. (158.) < .

< Judge Buggies, in the Chemung Canal Bank v. Judson, (8 N. Y. Rep. 259,) quoted with approbation the following *200remarks in Elliott v. Piersoll, (1 Peters, 328, 340 :) “ The rule is well declared that when a court * * * acts without authority, its judgment and orders are regarded as nullities. They are not voidable, but simply void, and form no bar to a recovery sought (even prior to a reversal) in opposition to them. * •* * This proves that the jurisdiction of any court exercising authority over a subject, may be inquired into in every other court, when the proceedings of the former are relied on, and brought before the latter by the party claiming the benefit of such proceedings and then added: “ The power of this court, therefore, to inquire into the jurisdiction of the District Court of the Hnited States is undoubted, and the power of that court to inquire into the jurisdiction of this, is equally clear.”

Judge Allen stated in Dobson v. Pearce, (12 N. Y. Rep. 164,) that “ The jurisdiction of the court in which a judgment has been recovered is, however, always open to inquiry, and if it has exceeded its jurisdiction, or has not acquired jurisdiction of the parties by the due service of process, or by a voluntary appearance, the proceedings are coram non judice, and the judgment void. The want of jurisdiction has always been held to be a valid defense to an action upon the judgment, and a good answer to it when set up for any purpose •” and Judge Denio held in Hatcher v. Rocheleau, (18 N. Y. Rep. 92,) that although in a court of general jurisdiction, it was unnecessary to prove that the defendant was served with process, or appeared in court, yet the defendant was at liberty to controvert those facts.

Thus, we see that Chancellor Walworth and Judges Bronson, Paige, Buggies, Allen and Denio, all. concurred in the view, that the judgment of every court will be void for want of jurisdiction, and that the recitals of jurisdictional matters, in the record of the judgment of any court, do not,' of themselves, preclude the showing by affirmative proof dehors the record that the recitals are untrue. I do not understand this doctrine to be denied by any court in any state of the Hnion, or by any of the Hnited States courts, *201or by any English court. It is certainly not denied by any decision of the courts of this state. If any case can be found which appears to controvert it, it must either be explicable on a theory consistent with such doctrine or be considered as unsound, at least in this state. It rests on sound principles, and having been so often reiterated by many of the most distinguished judges of this state, must be taken to be its established law.

One ease seems to intimate some different doctrine. (Sheldon v. Wright, 5 N. Y. Rep. 516.) The learned judge who delivered the opinion of the court in that case, says, referring to cases cited from 15 John. 141; 19 id. 33; and 9 Cowen, 229, that the distinguished judges, in their remarks ■in these cases, “ doubtless intended only to say, that the want of jurisdiction might always be set up against a judgment when it appears on the record, or was presented in any other unexceptionable manner.” What meaning he attached to the phrase, “ any other unexceptionable manner ”is not very clear. If he meant simply that, as a rule of evidence, the want of jurisdiction should be proved clearly and without a reasonable doubt, no exception can be taken to the phrase. The remark was made (on page 516) in discussing the point, whether a recital in an order made by a surrogate, to the following effect: “ Whereas, said order to show cause was immediately published for four weeks successively, and no cause shown at the time and place specified in said order or any time since,” was conclusive evidence of the facts recited or not. The learned judge held that it was; but held also that, as matter of fact, the publication had been duly made; a majority of the court concurred with him in affirming the judgment, but whether on the ground of the conclusiveness of the recitals, or on the ground of the truth in fact of such recitals, does not appear. If it is claimed that the effect of that opinion was, that the bare recital was conclusive evidence of the facts recited, then the decision would stand thus: The learned judge had held, (p. 511,) that the same rules as *202to jurisdiction applied to a surrogate’s court as to other courts of inferior jurisdiction; but he had also held, (p. 513,) that the publication of the order to show cause was necessary to the acquisition of jurisdiction by the surrogate. His decision, therefore, must have been that the recital of a jurisdictional fact even in the proceedings of an inferior court, is conclusive which is in direct opposition to the opinion of Judge Mullin in Potter v. Merchants’ Bank, (28 N. Y. Rep. 653, 654,) as well as many other cases. The question, in fact, was, whether jurisdiction had been obtained over the person; the learned judge conceded that the publication of the order to show cause for the length of time, and in the manner prescribed by the statute, was necessary, there having been no appearance to confer jurisdiction; he also conceded that a judgment rendered by a court or officer not having jurisdiction of the subject and the parties, was not conclusive, and yet held that the recital of a jurisdictional fact in the record is an adjudication of its existence, and as such con-.. elusive against one who has not appeared, and who has had no opportunity to appear and defend. I say one who has no opportunity to appear and defend; for, it is well settled that in judgment of law one who' has not been properly brought into court, is, unless he has voluntarily appeared, to be regarded as having had no opportunity to appear and defend. The result is, that a court having no jurisdiction over a person, might, in his absence, without giving him the notice required by statute, adjudicate that it had jurisdiction, proceed, and render judgment against him, and absolutely preclude him from questioning either the judgment or the adjudication, or the question of jurisdiction. This case, therefore, cannot be regarded as binding- authorthority, that the bare fact of there being recitals in the record of a judgment, of facts showing jurisdiction over the subject matter, precludes the party against whom the judgment js rendered, from disproving them in an action where such judgment is relied on.

This leads me to a consideration of the authorities cited *203by the respondent in support of his claim that the granting of letters testamentary by the surrogate of New York, is conclusive evidence of all the facts necessary to give him jurisdiction.
